summary: The Department of Homeland Security purchases many systems—such as for nuclear detection and search and rescue—that help it execute critical missions. And, while it has improved its management of major acquisitions, its non-major acquisitions (generally those that cost less than $300 million) haven't received as much attention—though DHS did make improvements during the course of our audit. We found that DHS planned to spend more...
title: Homeland Security Acquisitions: Identifying All Non-Major Acquisitions Would Advance Ongoing Efforts to Improve Management
